Pain & I are best friends. I've never broken a bone either, but I have also go through various forms of mega pain. I one time fell off a teeter totter after going too Cowboy crazy on it & I landed/sprained by tailbone for at least 7 hours. When I was young, I put my fingers in the way of the window while it was rolling up & it permanently squished my middle finger into an long oval shape. One time, during Middle School, the 2 student cafeteria workers thought it would be fun to race tossing out the trash. While doing so, they accidentally locked the doors behind them & neither of them wanted to left go of their push carts that they used to take out the pizza boxes. Now in my Middle School's cafeteria, the doors to the dumpster is also the door to another parking lot so it's an openable door for anyone who isn't just staff. Being a nice guy, I hard them knocking & I opened the door & tries to move out of their way before they barreled on through. Unfortunately, they went into Nascar mode & speed into the cafeteria at Mock 300 which gave me little to no time to react & they both ran over all 10 of my toes. They ran over my toes so hard that it activated a dormant gene in my body for ingrown toenails at an early age. I had to ice my toes the whole day &, many months later, had to get most of my toenails removed so I wouldn't get an infection from them later in life. And those, were just 3 examples of some of the crazy times I have gotten hurt. Just 3!

The punching bag one reminded me of my own story with a punching bag. So when I was 13 I had a punching bag (because anger issues). I got bored one day and had energy that I needed to release so into the garage where the punching bag was I went. I was getting bored of the whole punching thing so I though â€œwell maybe I could kick thisâ€. That went pretty alright until I decided to do a roundhouse kick. WORST. DECISION. EVER. My right knee (which was on the leg I used to kick) decided to fail me. Iâ€™m still 99% sure that my knee bent fucking sideways and though my mom denies it, I think that it may have momentarily dislocated before snapping back into position. Of course, I started screaming bloody murder until my mom came in. She was mad because I was yelling and at the time, we lived in a townhouse complex thing so we shared walls with neighbors. That anger mostly went away though when she saw me on the ground and holding onto my knee. She got me to the couch and iced it up. I could barely bend it for several days after that and for the next few months, there were occasional stints where it would just give out and fold in like a lawn chair. These instances were EXTREMELY painful and made it difficult to bend for days afterwards. Only after the time when it gave out right after a musical rehearsal did she finally think â€œyeah maybe we should get things checked outâ€. Cue a few months of physical therapy to end off 2021 (for context, the initial injury happened in January of 2021). That worked UNTIL March or early April of 2023. My dog got away from me and there was nearly TWO FEET of snow on the ground. I tried to trudge through the snow and then my knee felt off again. It felt weaker and it had almost given out on me a couple of times since then. I still havenâ€™t gotten it checked out again. I think that something more is wrong but Iâ€™m not really being heard out. Itâ€™s still being a pain in the ass. It has never felt completely stable and it feels like one wrong move will cause it to go all fucky again. So now Iâ€™m stuck with that all because my dumb ass 13 year old self decided to kick a punching bag.

Personal experience I've broken bones, shattered bones and tore soft tissue. By far the soft tissue damage hurt way more than shattered bones. Healing time is a fraction of fractured bones but severely more painful.   Edit. These stories bring so many painful memories to the forefront. My annoying step sister wouldn't give me privacy in the bathroom so I forced the door shut... On her finger... She got me back a few years later by spelling a rock onto my pinky. We were filling in holes so our was not her intention but I did life a nail that day. She never stopped feeling bad and apologising though and I never forgot that pain. Hey mom came out after just saving my brother from choking on a toothing cookie only to hear me scream blue murder. She was going to use my dad's tactic to calm me down "are you bleeding, are you crying, then your ok" but instead of getting a "no" for both questions she asked if I was bleeding I looked down and confirmed in my most scared 8 year old son scream "yes* and I was rushed to a hospital.  Edit, edit. Frost bite is a fun experience. I, too, am in constant pain. I have hypermobility, which means I am extra flexy. But, this comes with a cost. Because I am extra flexy, my muscles and tendons are always being tortured. Tendons don't go back to normal like muscles do. If I make one wrong move, my tendons will never be the same, and I will be in pain forever. I also have a problem with my jaw where it clicks all the time, and if I move wrong, it's very very painful, same with my hips, and knees. I can dislocate my shoulders on will, but because they're so loose, I have to make a conscious effort to pop them back into the sockets. There's a lot of other problems with my body, but yeah. I also have a uterus that sadly works, and I get headaches a lot. I am in constant pain, but I have never been too bad for long. Except for 4th grade where I wore boots that were too small for my first day of school. My ankles still haven't healed, almost 5 years later.

Two stories about two siblings (AKA me and my brother)  I have a dog. She likes to go on walks, and will (or used to) charge at dogs when she sees them. She doesnâ€™t bite, she just wants to play with them. I was scared of walking her, but this one night I decided to hold the leash and walk her. We turned a corner where there was a lady with two dogs. My dog lunged forward, launching me straight into the middle of the street. I just remember lying there paralyzed. Luckily I broke no bones. That dog can fling you fast. Iâ€™ve never walked her since, due toâ€¦ trama. I had three wounds on my knees and elbow, and the spots where the wounds were were red-ish for the next few years.   And now my brotherâ€™s story. One time we were playing in his room. In the corner of the room there was a closet with a sliding glass door that doubled as a mirror. My brother had got me in the closet and was moving the door back and forth so I couldnâ€™t get out, when the door gave out and dislodged from the â€œcloset-frameâ€. My brother noticed and caught it right before it hit my head and probably wouldâ€™ve killed me, and then tried to set it down as I went near the exit of the room. My brother tried to set it down and failed, without really realizing it. Now this probably wouldnâ€™t have been much of a deal, if there wasnâ€™t something wrong with his bed, resulting in a mattress low down to the ground. He tripped over it as the glass mirror door fell and crashed on his bookshelf, and shattered. Shards of glass flew around the room and a few went straight into my brotherâ€™s ankle, making a wound about the size of a pineapple. He had to get stitches and we stayed up all night in the hospital before he had to wear a cast and use crutches for a few months.  Pretty scarring stuff, both mentally and physically.

My own story, though not like i could avoid it. When i was 5, i woke up one day and my neck hurt sooo bad. It felt like a burning hot steel ball with spikes on it. As i said, it hurt and i was 5 and as a result i cried. Hard. The crying you get that hours after your done your still sniffling. My dad didnt know what was going on and because i was a massive crybaby he deducted that i lost a game and was angry. I fondly remember saying, "but it hurts!" And my dad had a little freakout. I slept in the top bunk at the time and so he rushed up to carry me down. I had an absence on my neck(like a big, puss filled ball) and had to stay in a hospital bed for like 3 weeks, though it felt like 8.  Another story for my dad. He fell down from my bunk and his back landed on the edge of a paint can. I remember him yelling curse words and i was still 5 so i was just llike "ok" and moved on. He also pinched his nerve between his bones while carrying a car battery like a shopping basket. Long stories short, pain.

I had cut my toenails the day before, so nothing protected that area. I didnâ€™t feel any pain so I just continued walking up the stairs until I looked down at my toe and I saw blood and blood was just trailing down the stairs. My dad told me to sit in the bathtub and turn on the water so that I could clean off my bleeding toe, it was bleeding like crazy! My dad rushed out the door and went to go clean up the blood that was trailing to our room, it looked like someone had been murdered and dragged into our room! My dad came upstairs with awful hotel Band-Aids and we just went to my bed and put them on. My toe hurt like crazy it was awful. Where my skin had dragged, there was just a skin flap there. I'm due to have another serious accident any day now. I'm eleven years old and will turn twelve in three months. The last (and first) time I had a serious accident was when I was about eight years old. I had just learned how to ride a bike and was going downhill for the first time. At the end of the hill, I wanted to stop, so I put my foot on the ground. Long story short, I went flying. I screamed for help, and the nearest person ran toward me. Once I got home, my mom told me to take a shower to clean the wound. It hurt a lot. When I was done, my mom put a bandage on it. I had it for a few days, then had a scab, which turned into a bruise. Eventually I was all healed, and now here I am posting a comment about it.

Knock knock whoâ€™s there tree, no one, treeâ€™s not here. Knock knock whoâ€™s there tree, who? Tree, who? OOOOOLLL (Now the tree is falling over, the joke doesnâ€™t work anymore). â€œLook buddy, that was clever and funny, but thatâ€™s not really something weâ€™re doing right now,â€ the PPTTJ will say, â€œthatâ€™s something for an old college friendâ€™s movie.â€ This is called concept rejection. This is a common problem and it is often the first stumbling block in any potential video marketing plan.  Now what?  This can be a difficult hurdle to clear. The PPTTJ is willing to discuss your content idea, but will be more interested in your existing product or service (the real audience). Here are some questions that can help determine whether you are right for each other:  What is your industry and what is the positioning of your product or service?  Who are your competitors?  Do you have a history of successful campaigns and ad placements in the same space?  Are you willing to pay me for this service?  Does your offer fit in with the messaging and target audiences I already have established?  Has your product or service already been successfully positioned in the marketplace?  How much do I really need your service?  What is my budget for new campaigns?  Are you willing to spend that budget on my existing audience?  Are you willing to be paid upfront?  Iâ€™ll say this too. Once you have answered these questions and more, you are ready to get started creating videos, and if you stick with me for the next few weeks and review the tips above, you are on your way to creating a professional video marketing campaign for your business.  And if you liked this post, sign up for my mailing list for future tips.  See this post in video format  Jason is a filmmaker with three years of experience creating video for startups, nonprofits, and businesses. In addition to creating video marketing strategy and action plans, Jason is the founder of Proofwell, a business that helps companies with their content strategy and identity

hahahahahahahahaha
Got this in my recommendations and I will share a couple experiences of injury I recall from my youth. Both were back in my elementary school days. The first happened one day when I rushed into the back room of our house. I slipped on the rug that was put after the step from the kitchen to that room and then fell right down onto the ankle of the foot that didn't slip. Surprisingly there was no visible damage. In fact there was no pain at all as I had no feeling in that foot until around midnight. When all the agonizing pain hit me at once. Went to the doctor and found out I had bruised the bone of my ankle which to this day I question how that also didn't bruise my skin.  Anyway the second instance of pain was another one that didn't come with initial pain. I was walking back home from school, it was a long walk as I had to transfer from the closer one for....reasons. Anyway as I walked a rather nice old woman drove up next to me and asked how I was walking. This lead to confusion until I looked down at my foot and saw a long piece of wood sticking about an inch into the flesh of my calf just a bit above my ankle. Then like an idiot...I pulled it out. After which came pain but then a nice ride home with the nice old lady whom didn't even reprimand me for the stupidity I was already hating myself for. Luckily apart from some bleeding there was no issues as the result of this. Save for me paying more attention to where I'm stepping.
I've had a wide range of pain

I broke my arm bone.
I relate so much to the whole "well you've never broken a bone, your pain is irrelevant!" shtick, my mother used it a lot along with "You'll never have a baby, so you wouldn't know what true pain is like" my how the turns have tabled.. partialy.  Either way, there is no "true pain" or whatever, pain is pain gosh darn it. Broken bone or simple paper cut it doesn't matter, it freaking hurts so quit this stupid garbage. To the parents out there, or even younger peeps, please stop telling people that are showing signs of being in pain that any form of pain they experience unless it's a broken bone is "stupid" and they need to "get stonger", "deal with it" and "grow up" or whatever. To parents especially, it's your duty to care for you child, if you do stuff like this it honestly just makes them annoyed or reluctant to talk to you about pain they might be experiencing and so they end up holding things in from you, even if it could be a life threatening pain in their chest or something. Look after your kids and don't tell them their nervous system is lying to them, it's there for a reason.

Heres one of my stories =â–·: so when I was younger (5) me and my little brother had a babysitter, just like any normal kid who came from where I lived at the time, and she had a dog who mainly stayed outside. Weeellll she also had a big tree with a wood swing (and wood plank with rope)so me and my Little siblings went over to my babysitter's house and were playing on the swing. We were screaming and giggling because thats what kids do. Well it was my turn, I was having fun screaming and laughing. My babysitter's dog was barking because she thought we were getting hurt. Then my babysitter moved the dog closer to us so she could play with us. The dog had a long enough chain to get right beside me and bit the swing. But instead she bit my hip. I screamed and my babysitter saw it all so she came and got me off the swing, lifted the side of my shirt that got bit, and it was purple and bleeding. My mom came running out of the house and rushed me to the car and got me to stop crying. When we got to urgent care the nurses or sum wrapped a bandage around my waist and called it a day. I still have the scar to this day. The end XD

Heres a pain story, i was a bit young when this happend and i was just laying down, when somehow my knee dislocated, may not sound like it hurts more then a broken bone, but it is because it lingers and over time to continues to get worse and worse, i had to take a tinkle winkle at the time so i was in a terrible time, took ambulance a coll 8 hours to get to my place give me laughing gas aka the good stuff i felt high and they snapped it back, my left knee was the one that got it, i couldent move and i was feeling sore, all around all day, now i hate hospitals, but that laughing gas is some good stuff, anyways done with the ramblings bye bye
well here's my i-almost-died-very-recently-but-miraculously-was-only-minorly-injured story:  i have chronic low blood pressure, which means i get dizzy very often and sometimes faint since my heart rate is slower than average. i am also an older teen, which is part of the age group most prone to fainting because of drastic hormone changes. so it doesn't come as a surprise that i faint quite often if i don't take care of myself properly and specifically. a few months ago, i was sitting on my bed upstairs and my grandma called me downstairs for something, so i jumped up and practically ran the few steps it took to get from my room to the top of the stairs since it was right outside the door. i had been doing homework all day and hadn't realized that i didn't eat anything yet at all, since the medication i take can get rid of my appetite, and it was around 6 pm. so i'm standing at the top of the stairs and i stop because i started to feel really dizzy, and before i had time to process anything i blacked out. when this happens, it feels like my brain literally shuts down. i have no memories, no feelings, i can't even think. im a blank slate. the main reason i know i fell forward was because the only thing i could feel was pain, and i couldn't even tell where at first. i later realized it was my face hitting the steps, and i also realized that the pain was the only thing that woke me up, otherwise i would've been slumped at the top of the stairs for a while if i had fallen backwards. when i opened my eyes i was still falling down the stairs but i had turned on my back and was flailing to try and grab anything to try and stop me. i was super disoriented and basically running on instincts, so of course i was unfortunate enough to not grab anything to slow me down and my back crashes into the pile of stuff at the bottom of the landing. at that point both my grandparents and my sister were rushing over to stop me and get me up, but it still took me an entire 10-15 minutes to actually get all my senses back and become fully aware. i could've broken my neck the way i fell, but luckily i only got a few brush burns and a smal cut on my back. i now have a schedule for myself and my family constantly reminds me to eat and drink etc. moral of the story, take care of yourself! otherwise you could be putting yourself in dangerous situations that could be prevented.  if you read this whole thing, thanks!! i hope everyone has a great day/night! ğŸ’–

I hit one toe  and spent the next minute  making a sour face with tears streaming down my cheeks and the worst pain i've ever had. Worst part is, we went to the A and E and waited for an hour just for them to tell us they didn't serve children. then we got a taxi and went to a different hospital were it took about half an hour to an hour to get to our room and get me sorted out. in the end, no broken bones, they gave my a numbing medicine, crutches, and wrapped my toes up. also my dad who was driving me around the hospital in a wheel chair, lost his balance, and crashed into a wall, my toe near millimetres from hitting the concrete wall, which would have resulted in screaming like the child I was. Im glad i havent actually been in too many accidents, my two worst pains i can remember having were the one time i tried to climb the monkey bars we had at school. In winter, with ice covering it, wearing gloves, which had absolutely no grip to them. Naturally, i slipped, and landed face-first into the gravel below. It hurt a ton, but it didnt end up bleeding at all suprisingly, and only scabbed. The other time was when my dad came home from work on his motorcycle, and I greeted him in the garage. I ended up accidentally tripping and landing my leg on the VERY HOT METAL ENGINE and i had a burning pain in my leg for like 2 weeks
One time when I was 4 or 5, I taped 2 lego bricks together, but I wanted them to be seperate again, so like any sensible human, I used scissors. You know that piece of sort of webbed skin that connects your index finger to your thumb? Well the scissors slipped, and it went THROUGH it. All I remember is that there was a lot of blood, a lot of crying, and now I have a scar, an everlasting and eternally present reminder of my own mortality.

The â€œfunny bone" is actually a nerve. The ulnar nerve runs along the inside part of your elbow. It sends information to the brain from your pinky finger and the finger right next to it. It also controls some of your hand's movements.

I have nocturnal epilepsy, and when I have a severe seizure, it's the equivalent of a Special Attack in PokÃ©mon, compared to a Physical Attack. It's like being engulfed by the very essence of nightmare itself, and all the while, your mind feels the pain of 11000 suns burning it to a crisp, and just sitting up makes your head explode in pain, all the while your stomach will occasionally not want its contents in it anymore, but emptying it would cause your head to explode. On the upside, I've suffered extreme physical injuries during these, but have no recollection of them. I've banged my head, bashed my shin, scratched my face, and even gotten a gash from my collarbone down to my upper arm, but because my brain was busy being injected by the demon of nightmare itself, it doesn't realize that the rest of my body is a thing and pays it a no nevermind.

There was this one time when I was 7 years old. It was morning on Fourth of July. I was walking down the hallway of my house and then my uncle scared me, because y'know, he's an uncle. I screamed as I fells backwards into a corner and cut my head open. Fast forward, I got staples and now I have a scar that's almost impossible to see because of my long thick hair ğŸ˜ƒ
I've never broken a bone myself, but probably the worst I've ever been injured was when me and my cousin decided to ride in a wagon down a hill being pulled behind a tractor that a family friend of my cousins' was driving. At the bottom of the hill, he went to turn. Except then the wagon flipped. My cousin definitely got the worst of it because he was unlucky enough to be on the outside of where the wagon flipped, so he got launched from it like a catapult. Meanwhile I end up underneath the flipped wagon like a crab. My aunt and uncle just looked down the hill and saw me staggering back up the hill with a bunch of scrapes, cuts, and bruises. So yeah, that was painful. I ended up with literal rocks embedded into my knees that we had to get out, too. I can't remember exactly how bad my cousin got hurt, but he wasn't any better than I was. As bad as that was, now, several years later, I see that as a funny story of stupidity and bad judgment that led to a situation that's kinda funny in hindsight.

Oh, you want pain? Lemme tell YOU a story about my pain...  One time, I went on a field trip with my class (it wasn't a FIELD trip, but you get it) to Twin Rinks. As I was getting my skates on, this random person who wasn't from my school at all decided to just stomp on my exposed foot (no skate on it). Fortunately, it wasn't that hard, but UNFORTUNATELY, he had skates on, so it hurt like HECC. So, I had to wait 10 minutes until I finally stood up, and another 10 just to put the skate on. Anyway, when I FINALLY got to the ice, I immediately fell and hit my head on the corner of one of those big ol' doors that open to let in the Zamboni. Luckily, I already had my helmet on (the reason I said that is because the exact same happened to me one time, only I had my helmet off). While I was gaining my balance on the ice, I decided to take a break next to one of those penalty boxes (or whatever). The thick ol' door was open, and I stupidly put my hand to the hinge... The same person who stepped on my already painful foot decided to maim me even more and slammed the thick ol' door on my hand, and it didn't stop until it latched in and locked. I had to wait there with my hand making like a fountain and filling the ice up with blood until he decided to let me live and opened the door (legend has it the piece of flesh is still there to this day). I had to spend the rest of the week using a COMPUTER to do my school assignments. I still have the scar to this day.

related to the story of when you got your fingers slammed in your brothers door: a similar thing happened to me except it was my mom who slammed my fingers and not a sibling. i was really young and really really small, so i was standing by my mom just outside the laundry room but she couldn't see me. i put my fingers between the door and the wall, and mom finished what she was doing so she left the room and tried to close the door. she couldn't close the door because my fingers were in the way of course so she got confused and slammed harder. now i was doing the thing kids do where their mouths are open and they are trying to scream and cry but they can't because they are in too much pain to get air out, so she didn't hear OR see me. she tried slamming the door maybe one more time before looking down and seeing that her stupid child was just sitting there with their fingers still in the door  and if you're wondering, the reason i didn't move my fingers was because i was in too much pain to think reasonably, plus i was a dumb toddler. i was more focused on getting noise out. my fingers are fine now of course, though i would like to think the reason one of my fingers is double jointed is because of that finger slamming thing :]

List of worst pains *i* have felt  1. sinus headache, i know nowhere near a migraine or cluster headache but i was in class and suddenly my mind just went blank and a few seconds later my eyebrows started hurting and after my nose and then near my cheeks, i have had a handful of these headaches since but i just tune it out know 2.Tension headaches, I just get short tension headaches when im zoning out of focusing too much i ignore them now too 3. Electric shock, i was an idiot and i put my finger in a lamp that was on but had no light bulb in. 4. Wasp sting on the palm of my hand, i was four ok leave me alone it hurt  5. *THE BIG ONE* so i was at my school gym and i was on a machine that had big bulky like idk Pedals, (ok i looked it up and just search this "walking glider exercise machine" and imagine it being twice the size of the average 10 year old) and i was walking fast on it and my foot, SLIPPED and it got crushed between the pedals and was just mangled between the pedals i of course went 3:28 and my PE teacher said i kid you not "You alright?" SO I JUST LET OUT THE MOST BLOOD CURDLING SCREAM MY FRIENDS ARE RUNNING OVER TO ME AND ASKING ME WHATS WRONG and he comes out 15 seconds later with a pot of jelly A POT OF FRICKING JELLY,  i was taken out of school and got permission to leave class early for a while.  *bonus* i stubbed my toe on my cousin's plastic slide like a year ago, and broke it  i had a school trip the next day to walk around a giant city with a broken toe ON CRUTCHES, i just remember walking up the steps to a train station going slow for my own safety and a teacher had to run out from the platform to help me up so i did not miss the train, and thats it my own little story

It was in Manhattan. Little 5 or 6 years old me was playing on the swings in the park. I thought it would be SUPER DANK if I jumped off the swing, and land perfectly. And so I did exactly that. Expect I didn't. I jumped off the swing, and landed my eye, right on the spiked fence. Immediate Black Out. I wake up in a hospital bed, with Toy Story 2 or 3 on the TV, and a Flat Stanley Book right next to me. The doctor came in with my parents and said they did stitches on my upper eye, and said that if I didn't get to a hospital in time, I would have lost my eye. Now I have a permanent scar on my upper right eye, right above my eyelid.                           AND IT WAS TOTALLY WORTH IT.

I've had worse pain.      Story 1:  as a kid there was this rectangle wood thingy (idk what its called) and I broke a toenail with it. I remember that it bled. blood was everywhere. it was painful. (I think I broke the big toe toenail on my right foot) but luckily, it grew back.  Story 2: one fateful summer day, there was this grill you put on a table or something like that, and my arm happened to just touch it. it hurt, cause I burned myself. a BIG scab grew where i burned myself. but one night my sister tried to get me to leave her room (cause she had a friend over) and hit the scab and peeled it back (I can see that people are probably cringing rn) and it hurt. if you were to touch where it was peeled back (where it was red) it stung. my parents gave me a nonstick adhesive pad and sprayed something (I forgot what it was called) on where it stung and then placed the adhesive nonstick pad on it. it stopped the stinging and I had to take a bath one day. I was scared that it would sting again, but luckily, it didn't. we got rid of the rest of the scab and it healed over time. (the end lol cause that's all I remember for story 2)

Story: Once when I was 6 I think, I was riding my neighbour's scooter up and down the sidewalk. I had already gone up and down so I was prepared for my impending doom. Right when my neighbour's nanny looked away the front wheel of the scooter ran over a pebble and the pebble got stuck, causing me with my full momentum to catapult into the ground face first at full speed. My forehead slammed into the ground so hard swear there was an audible thump. Being me I immediately got up returned the scooter and managed to make my way back to my house without falling over. I waddled upstairs and collapsed onto my bed and cried into my pillow. For the next 2 days I had a splitting headache.  Thus is the story of why I hate going faster than a walking pace on a scooter.

noww to tell you my PAINS!  first story: I was about 3-4 years old, and I was reaching to my mom, and the door slammed on my fingers. I cryed, and (this is not a joke I am dead serious) my soul left my body, I saw myself with teas and my mom holding me. when my soul went back into my body, me and my family were right outside the house.  second story: I stayed up late and I felt all the bones in my rib cage shake. the pain was so excrutiating I tried to faint, FAILED, and went to sleep.  third story: I stubbed my toe, and it didn't feel to bad at first. and the next thing I know Im in a wheelchair because of the pain.  fourth story: I got warts on my foot. one logical explination is that I shook an elementary school's teacher's hand, and somehow their hand warts transfered all the way from her hand into my foot. It wasn't to bad at first. it was very painful, but bearable. then about a few weeks later it started growing. my mom thought it was a good idea to put my feet in warm water. all 4 warts then merged into one big, disgusting wart. and one faithful day, I was brought to the hospital where they used a fucking knife to cut the warts off my foot. there is only one word to describe the pain, which is AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAH, but I had an elmo toy, and I was happy my family was there, so somehow I dialed it down to a nice, quiet, ow.   fourth story: I was 3-4 and I ran into a tree. My Story- I don't really remembered about this, but my parents have been telling me this story multipl times. And I do have a little memory about what happened.  I was around the age 4 or maybe 3 at that time, and I was playing with my two older brothers. I was the youngest and only daughter. When we were playing and running back a forth in the hallway, I fell and hit my head at the corner of the wall. And it hit me pretty hard. I began to cry and my head was bleeding. When my mom was wiping the blood, she showed me the blood and I stopped crying. I was just staring at the blood all surprised. Until my mom saw something on my head, she can see a white spot. I remembered telling the story to my childhood friend and she freaked out. She told me that it's either your mucsle or your skull.  Anyway, they took me to the hospital and the doctors where stitching my forehead. But while they were doing that, I was talking so much to the doctors, they don't even understand of what I am saying. My dad told me that I like to talk a lot and most of the time, no body would understand me what I'm saying. Just babbling words. Kinda funny once I think about it. Now I don't really remmebered everything, but I do remmembered celabrating my birthday and my grandpa birthday. We decided to celebrate on the same day. At that time, I rememmbered wearing a bad-aid on my head. Now I have the scar for the rest of my life
